Chapter 6, part 2: Distinguishing the Sages, here some other schools say:
There is definitely no real pleasure, only suffering in feeling.
How do we know this?
Because of reasoning and teachings.
What are the reasons?
Because suffering increases later.
That is to say, if one dwells for a long time in all activities and deportment, one can obtain increasing suffering later.
Reasonably, there is definitely no cause of dwelling in pleasure that can make suffering gradually increase later, therefore we know that there is definitely no real pleasant feeling.

Moreover, because there is activity in the cycle of birth and death. That is to say, having activity is a characteristic of the cycle of birth and death. The body has activities such as bathing and eating, and the mind has activities such as cognizing objects. Activities oppress and never bring peace, therefore there is no non-suffering in the cycle of birth and death.

Moreover, because of the subduing of superior pleasure by slight suffering, that is, when slight suffering produced by the causes of mosquitoes, gadflies, and wind is present, it is able to subdue the superior pleasure produced by the causes of bathing, anointing, eating, sleeping, etc., and prevent it from being present. Therefore the contaminated aggregates are only of the nature of suffering.
Moreover, because fools give rise to the conceit of superior pleasure in the midst of the oppression of heavy suffering that is to be counteracted.

That is, if one is not oppressed by the suffering of hunger, thirst, cold, heat, fatigue, and desire, etc., then one does not give rise to the perception of pleasure in that which counteracts it. Therefore the perception of pleasure arises from the counteraction of suffering, not from the arising of pleasure. Therefore there is no real pleasure.
Moreover, because the perception of pleasure arises in the state of easy deliverance from various sufferings.
Based on this meaning, there is a verse that says:
Just as when carrying a heavy load one changes shoulders, or when tired one stops to rest,
The world, by this suffering, is delivered from that suffering as well.
Therefore, the class of foolish people have the perception of pleasure in suffering, but there is no real pleasure.
By what teaching?
As the World-Honored One said:
All that is felt is not non-suffering.
Also, the sutra says:
When this arises, suffering arises; when this ceases, suffering ceases.
Also, the sutra says:
Regarding suffering as pleasure is called the perversion of conceptualization, and so on.
Also, the sutra says:
You should contemplate pleasure as suffering.
This is what the Abhidharma masters of other schools all say, that there is definitely real pleasure.
How do we know this?
Because the power of the causes of pleasure and suffering is different, their substance is truly different, just like greed and hatred.

It is currently seen that the causes of greed and hatred are different, and after arising from different causes, their power is also different. Because the causes are different, their difference is well established.

The causes of pleasure and suffering are also seen to be different in the world. It is seen that suffering arises from the mutual opposition of the great elements, and pleasure arises from their harmony.
The function of the cause of differentiation is also different from that of the cause of birth. Suffering harms, while pleasure benefits.
Because the function of the cause of birth is seen to be different, we definitely know that apart from suffering there really is a substance of pleasure.
The Sthavira also says this:

Although there is no lack of a state of feeling that benefits in the present, it has not yet transcended the category of suffering, because contaminated dharmas are only causes of suffering. Therefore, feeling in saá¹ƒsÄra is only suffering.
This is also unreasonable.
Why is it so?

Because it contradicts what you have said, because it only establishes a thesis, because it would result in something undesirable, and because it is not established.ğŸ”½As for contradicting what you have said, if there is no lack of a state of feeling that benefits, then it should not be only suffering.
If you say it is only suffering, then it should not benefit. The principle should only say that in the state of inferior suffering there is slight harm and no benefit is allowed.

The only thing they establish is that pleasure does not transcend the category of suffering, but they do not give a reason. How do you know that the experience of pleasure does not transcend the category of suffering?
The second reason is that in their system, faith and craving do not transcend the category of thought. In that case, these two must be identical, because the pure and the defiled would be mixed.
Liberation would be without the fault of being defiled, because they are not mixed. Pleasure and suffering are the same in being experiences, but they are different.
The third reason is that in samsara, there is definitely no pleasure, because it is not established. In that case, contaminated dharmas are also causes of pleasure.
Because we admit that there is the experience of pleasure. How can you say that all contaminated dharmas are only causes of suffering, and therefore prove that pleasure is suffering?
Therefore what they say has words but no meaning.

Also, you must definitely admit that there is a real experience of pleasure that is different from suffering, because there is a difference between the two in that one is loved and the other is not loved.
If you say that the nature of pleasure is not established because it becomes unpleasant when one is free from passion,
this is also unreasonable, because when one is free from passion, one views it as unpleasant from a different perspective.
The practitioner does not view the aspect of pleasure as unpleasant, but rather becomes disgusted with pleasant feeling through other characteristics, as will be explained later.
Moreover, there really is pleasant feeling apart from pain, because the Buddha said it exists in the scriptures.
As a scripture says:
There are three kinds of feeling, namely pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant.
If the intrinsic nature of feeling is all painful, what benefit is there in the Buddha's teaching of the three feelings?

If you say that the World-Honored One taught according to the world, meaning that the world gives rise to the awareness of pleasure, etc. in the lower, higher, and middle states of pain respectively, and the World-Honored One taught the three of pleasure, etc. according to that,
this is also unreasonable, because it is not universally accepted.
The third feeling is not universally accepted in the world, so how can the World-Honored One teach it according to the world?
Therefore it is said that the three feelings are based only on true seeing.

Also, in speaking of the contemplation of pleasant feeling, the Buddha used the words â€œin accordance with reality.â€ Therefore one should not speak of the existence of three feelings in accordance with worldly convention. Lower painful feeling is not really pleasant.
Also, because pleasure also has three kinds, lower, etc., one should not say that pleasure is only lower painful feeling.
Also, because non-meritorious action would produce a pleasant result. Non-meritorious action is admitted to be of three grades. The lowest grade can produce a result that is lower painful feeling.
You say that lower painful feeling is in reality pleasure. Would it not be that non-meritorious action would produce a pleasant result?
Also, as painful feeling becomes lower and lower, so pleasure becomes higher and higher.

When the lowest grade of non-meritorious action produces the lowest grade of pain, according to your theory, the lowest grade of pain is the highest grade of pleasure. How can a low cause produce a high result?
This contradicts the principle of the correspondence between cause and result.
Also, as painful feeling becomes lower and lower, so pleasure becomes higher and higher.
Then, inferior non-meritorious karma as a cause would be able to produce superior pleasant feeling as a result. Who would then do good and expend great effort?
Moreover, meritorious and non-meritorious karma each have nine grades. How could inferior non-meritorious karma as a cause produce superior pleasant feeling as a result?

Moreover, superior meritorious karma and inferior non-meritorious karma would both produce inferior painful feeling as a result. Then, meritorious and non-meritorious karma would be without distinction.
The same objection applies to the other eight grades.
Moreover, a single result would be produced by two causes. Or it would be necessary to admit that merit is itself demerit. This would contradict the teachings of the TathÄgata.

Moreover, the three lower concentrations are admitted to have pleasant feeling. In the upper stages, there is only neither-pleasant-nor-unpleasant feeling. Who knows that painful feeling is inferior, and that superior and middling are superior? Even if one expends great effort, one tires of the inferior and delights in the superior?
Moreover, as concentration gradually becomes superior, you hold that pain gradually increases. Who could be more unreasonable than this?
If a weak suffering is called pleasure, then pleasant feeling would not be a very intense experience, and it would not be reasonable for a weak feeling to be clearly experienced.
If you hold that a weak feeling is clearly experienced, then a medium feeling would be unclearly experienced. Who with intelligence would accept such a doctrine?
Therefore we know that apart from suffering there really is a pleasant feeling.

Also, they may give rise to other doctrines that are erroneous. If pleasure and suffering have no different substance, then it is possible for others to give rise to other doctrines. They may say that only the state of separation from what is lovable gives rise to the perception of suffering in the absence of pleasure, and there is no separate suffering. This is an erroneous doctrine.

Or it is possible to hold the view that only the feeling of pleasure really exists and the other feelings do not really exist, and that the three feelings of pleasure, etc., are established in order in the superior, medium, and weak states of the feeling of pleasure.
This is because their reasoning is no different from the previous doctrine.

Just as they hold that only suffering exists because of the power of their own discrimination, and that the three feelings are established according to the degree of suffering, so it is in this case. Therefore their doctrine is not good.

Also, the two feelings of pain and pleasure are definitely real and different, because the scriptures say that the six sense bases are the heavens, the world, and the hells, and there are distinctions among them.
A scripture says:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that there are six sense bases called the heavens and the world. If sentient beings are born there, the eyes see only agreeable forms and none that are disagreeable.
In detail, it is said that because of this, there is only the experience of joy and pleasure there.
There are six sense bases called the hells, which are the opposite of the above, and this should be explained in detail.
The name â€œpleasureâ€ for the lesser suffering below has already been refuted above, so it cannot be said that joy and pleasure are provisional names.
If there is no real pleasure, the scriptures should only say:
The heavens and the world have only lesser suffering, and the hells have only greater suffering.
Moreover, the repeated mention of â€œonlyâ€ would be useless, because it would be said that the agreeable is only agreeable, and then that there is only the experience of joy and pleasure.

If you say that the name â€œpleasureâ€ is provisionally established for a small amount of suffering, then there is both suffering and pleasure in a single feeling. How can you say that it is entirely pleasure?
Therefore the theory of the Ä€bhidharmikas is not reasonable.
Also, because the scriptures use the term â€œas it really is,â€ we know that there really is a pleasant feeling.
A scripture says,
â€œWhen one experiences a pleasant feeling, one understands as it really is that one is experiencing a pleasant feeling.
The same is said of painful and neutral feelings.â€
Also, a scripture says,ğŸ”½â€œYou should know that the faculty of pleasure and the faculty of joy are both pleasant feelings.â€
It continues extensively in this vein.
It also says,
â€œIf one sees these five faculties with right wisdom as they really are, one will eliminate three of the bonds.â€
If feelings are only suffering, how can it be said that one understands as it really is that this is a pleasant feeling?
Therefore we know that the intrinsic nature of pleasant feeling is pleasure.
However, their claim that there is no real pleasure because later pain increases is unreasonable, because the causes of the arising of pain and pleasure are not only objects.

We do not admit that the power of external objects alone can generate pain and pleasure. If objects alone were the cause, then when one first engages in activities and deportment, one should immediately generate a feeling of extreme pain.
That is, because these objects at the final moment become the conditions that generate extreme pain, one has already engaged with such objects at the beginning.
If pain and pleasure were generated by the power of objects alone, then when the object is first encountered, one should generate the highest degree of pain;
Since this is not the case, we know that the body's continuum and state transform and change, and external objects then become the causes of the generation of pain and pleasure.

That is, when the basis reaches such a state, cold, warm, and other contacts can become the causes of pleasure. There is no principle that when they reach this time, they are not the causes of pleasure. As for being the causes of pain, the principle should be the same. Therefore, observing the separate causes, we make external objects the causes of the generation of each of the feelings of pain and pleasure.
Therefore, you should not deny the existence of real pleasure because of the increased suffering that arises later due to activities, etc.

It is seen in the world that earth, water, and manure, etc., are the causes for the arising of sprouts, leaves, etc., through observing the differences in the transformations of the series and states.
Why is it that the various postures, etc., are only able to give rise to suffering later, not at the beginning?
Because after a long time, the body becomes tired and exhausted, and different primary elements arise in the body, which then give rise to the feeling of suffering later.

Because external objects must depend on other causes in order to be able to be the causes that give rise to the feelings of pleasure and suffering, therefore the causes of the arising of pleasure and suffering are not indeterminate.
Also, one cannot say that because suffering increases later, suffering was already produced at the beginning.
If one says that because suffering is seen to arise later due to the various postures, etc., suffering was already produced at the beginning,
then one should hold that because the arising of the noble pleasure is seen in the later stage of ordinary beings, the noble pleasure was already produced in the past.
In this case, one can also make such a conjecture:
Because the subtle, prior, holy bliss is not known, but later, as it gradually increases, it is perceived as existing.
Then there is the error that there is no final distinction between ordinary beings and saints.
If you say that the cause of abiding in bliss cannot be cultivated, so that later suffering gradually increases, and therefore you know that there is definitely no real blissful feeling,
then if there is a cause of abiding in bliss that can be cultivated, and later suffering does not increase,

then the three lower meditative absorptions should really have the feeling of bliss. If there is no real bliss in the three meditative absorptions, then it should not be said that later suffering increases because of the existence of bliss.
Therefore we know that there definitely is no real blissful feeling, because it is not permanent.
A scripture says:
The meditative absorptions and formless states are also called suffering.
It is not because they have the nature of harm.

Moreover, when one observes the faults of the lower [realms] and attains freedom from attachment, it is not necessarily by observing them as having the nature of harm. Observing them as coarse hindrances also leads to freedom from attachment.
Moreover, aversion to the lower [realms] is not the only cause for freedom from attachment. Delight in the virtues of the higher [realms] is also a cause for freedom from attachment.
The virtues of the upper stages increase gradually, and one rejoices in them and is able to separate from the defilements of the lower stages. Therefore, one should not say that they are suffering.

If there were no worldly path, one would not be able to separate from those defilements. Since there are places where there are causes of definite happiness, there is self-nature happiness in the contaminated.
Therefore, their statement that later suffering increases and there is no real happiness is not a reasonable cause.
As for the statement that in the cycle of birth and death there is movement and therefore feeling is only suffering, that is also unreasonable, because the noble path should also have movement.
That is to say, if pleasant feeling has movement as a precursor, and then it is obtained, it is called having movement.
The noble path also has diligent effort as a precursor, and then it is realized and attained. It should have movement.
If pleasant feeling has something to which it clings, the noble path is also like that and should have movement. Then the truth of the path should also be suffering.
But that is not accepted, because it has already been explained.

Also, that treatise first admits that all dharmas are without movement, and later says that because birth and death have movement, there is no pleasure at all. This is contradictory, and therefore the reason given cannot prove anything.

As for the claim that because subtle suffering subdues superior pleasure, we know that there is no pleasure, this is also unreasonable, because we have already explained that it is due to other causes.

That is to say, we have already explained that objects are the cause of pleasure, and that they must depend on the distinctions of the great elements that are their supports. Therefore, the body that is being harmed by mosquitoes, gadflies, etc., cannot serve as a cause that assists bathing, etc., in producing the feeling of pleasure, because at that time one only feels suffering. One should not deny the existence of pleasure, because when there are causes that assist, pleasure is produced.
If the contaminated aggregates are only of the nature of suffering, then when bathing, etc., one would always produce suffering and not pleasure.

Because sometimes the body, in dependence on conditions, produces suffering, and sometimes it again depends on other conditions to produce pleasure. Therefore we know that the causes and conditions of suffering and pleasure are definite. Because the causes and conditions are definite, they must have separate natures.
If you say that when the body is cut with a saw, although it is in contact with the cause of pleasure, such as fragrant ointments, pleasure is not produced but only pain is produced,

we reply that when it is in contact with the cause of pleasure, such as fragrant ointments, if it is in contact with the cause of pain, such as mosquitoes and gadflies, then pleasure is not produced but only pain is produced. This is as explained above.

That is, we see that there are cases where only the cause of pleasure can produce pleasure and never pain, such as the three trance states. Because in the realm of desire, attachment to pleasure is slight, so when encountering a condition of pleasure, it cannot overcome pain.

However, there are also cases where the cause of pain produces pleasure, that is, we see that in the world, those who increase the taste of pain, by repeated practice, etc., give rise to delight in it.

Also, we see that in the world, red-hot iron and stone, etc., can initially serve as the cause of pleasure when they come into contact with the body, but if one becomes too familiar with them later, how can they still produce pleasure?
We have already explained that objects are the cause of pleasure and pain, but this depends on the distinction of the state of the support. Why do you still raise objections?
Or, because the kinds of suffering and pleasure are different, when they arise, they are naturally different. You should not use this example to infer that all conditioned dharmas are suffering.
Therefore the contaminated aggregates are not all of the nature of suffering, because a scripture says, the Buddha told MahÄnÄma:
If form were only suffering, not pleasure, not associated with pleasure, and so on at length, then sentient beings would not become attached to form.

As for the claim that fools generate the conceit of pleasure on the basis of the relief of intense suffering, and therefore there is no real pleasure, this is also unreasonable, because the existence of pleasure is proven by the fact that it is an antidote to suffering.

That is, if one seeks the dharma that is the antidote to suffering, then there is a real dharma that is the antidote to suffering. Since one seeks pleasure by generating superior practices in order to eliminate suffering, then there is real pleasure that is the antidote to suffering. What reason is there to deny this?
Also, after suffering is first eliminated, one enters the third trance state. What suffering is eliminated by the perception of pleasure in the third trance state?
Also, superior pleasure is generated on the basis of superior objects such as sound, smell, etc. What suffering is eliminated by this?
Therefore, the reason they give cannot refute the reality of pleasure.

As for the statement that the feeling of pleasure arises in the state of easy deliverance from various sufferings, and therefore there is no real pleasure, this is also unreasonable, because it has already been explained.
What has been explained previously?
It is said that the causes of pleasure and suffering are not only the objects.
If it were only the objects, then when first taking up the burden, there should immediately arise an intense feeling of suffering on the shoulders;
since this is not the case, when changing shoulders, one observes that the basis for the feeling of pleasure changes, and as long as it has not ceased, it can still be the cause of pleasure.

It should also not be said that the class of foolish common people have the feeling of pleasure arise from the arising of new suffering, because when first encountering a whip or other [painful stimulus], they should have the feeling of pleasure.
It is clearly seen that that suffering also has degrees of intensity, and when first experiencing the light [form], one should have the feeling of pleasure.
Or they should explain by what reason, when a heavy burden is on the shoulders for a long time and not easily removed, it causes intense suffering, but not so at first when it is easily removed.
It is not reasonable to say that only this heavy burden, when it is on the shoulders, is the cause of heavy suffering, and when it is on the hips, it produces light suffering.
Since the conditions are the same, how can suffering be heavy or light?
From this we know that there is something else that serves as the cause of suffering and happiness, namely, the distinction in the state of the body. Therefore, there is real happiness in samsara.
However, the World-Honored One's statement that all feelings are not non-suffering is not contradictory, because the Buddha himself explained it in the sutra.
It is said that Ananda asked the World-Honored One:

The Buddha said in other sutras that there are three kinds of feelings, namely, pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant. Based on what secret meaning did this sutra further say that all feelings are not non-suffering?
The Buddha said:
Ananda!
I said that all feelings are not non-suffering based on the secret meaning that all conditioned things are impermanent and all conditioned things are subject to change and destruction.ğŸ”½Ananda!

Therefore we know that this scripture speaks in terms of the two kinds of suffering and not in terms of the suffering of pain. The words â€œall is sufferingâ€ are not to be taken literally. Consequently, we know for certain that there really are three feelings. The Venerable ÅšÄriputra did not ask the Buddha, â€œIn what hidden meaning do you speak of three feelings?â€
The Buddha also did not say that he spoke of three feelings in a hidden meaning. He only said that he spoke of all as suffering in a hidden meaning.
Since he said that all is suffering in a hidden meaning, it is not the ultimate truth and cannot be relied on. How can we deny the existence of real pleasure on the basis of this?
A scripture says,
â€œWhen this arises, suffering arises. When this ceases, suffering ceases.â€
This also does not contradict the fact that contaminated dharmas are by nature associated with the three kinds of suffering.
Even though the substance of such things as the notion of form is not suffering, it is still said to be suffering, just as is the feeling of suffering.
In the same way, even though the substance of pleasure, etc., is not suffering, how does it contradict the statement that it is suffering, just as is the feeling of suffering?
Or, all contaminated dharmas are categorized as the truth of suffering. Speaking in this way is not contradictory.
How can we not prove the nonexistence of pleasure on the basis of this?

This is not so, because it has already been explained that what is not suffering is said to be suffering. That is, just as form, etc., which are not suffering are said to be suffering, so it is with pleasure, etc. What is not suffering is said to be suffering.
If this is so, then when one contemplates pleasure as the truth of suffering, how can one avoid falling into a mistaken state of mind?
This has already been explained.
What has already been explained?
It is said that it is because it is by nature the suffering of the process of becoming and the suffering of change.
In accordance with this interpretation, a verse states:
The Buddhas, the Perfectly Enlightened Ones, know that all conditioned forces are impermanent
And that what is conditioned changes and decays, and therefore they say that all feelings are suffering.

However, contaminated pleasure is difficult to create and easily destroyed. The practitioner is disgusted with it and contemplates it as suffering, not because pleasurable feeling is by nature suffering.
This is because suffering is easy to create and can be obtained at will. For example, by merely holding oneâ€™s breath, one can produce extremely painful feelings.
However, it is extremely difficult to destroy, and in order to make it cease, one must make great effort, and it still continues to exist.

Pleasure is not like this. Even if one makes great effort, it is still difficult to make it appear and remain for a long time. Therefore, practitioners generate extreme disgust and aversion towards pleasant feeling and view it as suffering. For this reason, pleasant feeling is also included in the truth of suffering.
Therefore, one cannot deny the intrinsic nature of pleasant feeling by saying that when this arises, suffering arises, and when this ceases, suffering ceases.
Also, the sutra's statement that to regard suffering as pleasure is called an inverted view is not contradictory, because to regard it as only pleasure constitutes an inverted view.

This means that contaminated pleasure is also called suffering, because pleasure arising and abiding is suffering when it perishes, because its nature is impermanent and included in the suffering of conditioned states. How can it not be inverted to regard it as only pleasure?

Moreover, due to the power of the view of grasping at what is superior, ordinary beings, who are completely burned by the fire of afflictions, consider contaminated conditioned states to have the quality of tranquility. Therefore, to consider suffering to be pleasure constitutes the inverted views of conceptualization, etc.

If you say that this is like the eternal self, etc., and that the idea of pleasure in regard to what is entirely suffering is a perversion, this is not so, because the scriptures deny that form, etc., are entirely suffering.

For this very reason, I have already admitted that both the addition of something that is not there and the addition of something to what is there are called perversions, and therefore the nonexistence of pleasure is not established by this.
Also, the scripture that says, â€œYou should contemplate pleasure as suffering,â€ is not contradictory, because the existence of pleasure is established by this very scripture.
The scripture says:
â€œYou bhiká¹£us should contemplate suffering in regard to pleasant feeling, and you should contemplate the impermanent in regard to neither-pleasant-nor-unpleasant feeling.â€
If the three feelings have only the nature of suffering, the Buddha should not have advised a specific contemplation of them;
but since he did advise a specific contemplation, we know that their natures are different.

In this case, the body of painful feeling is not a poisonous arrow, but it is harmful and is the same as a poisonous arrow, and therefore it is advised that suffering be contemplated as being like a poisonous arrow.
Thus, pleasant feeling by nature is not suffering, because its nature is pleasant.

Because it will certainly change and disappear, even though by nature it is pleasant, one is advised to contemplate it as suffering, because when it changes and disappears, it will certainly be suffering.
Just as when a clay pot is thrown into the air, even though its nature is still intact before it hits the ground, it is said to be broken.
Neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is also not impermanent, because its nature is feeling.
Because it will certainly be destroyed, even though it is not impermanent by nature, one is advised to contemplate it as impermanent, because after arising, it will certainly be destroyed later.
And because the characteristic of impermanence always follows it.

Because neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling cannot give rise to delusion, and because of delusion, one has already been destroyed for many eons, grasping it as permanent and as the self and what belongs to the self. In order to counteract that view of permanence and self, one is advised to contemplate neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling as impermanent.
Now, examining the meaning of the sutra, one is advised to contemplate in this way, in order to give rise to the practice of detachment from dharmas in the three realms.

That is, first one contemplates suffering with the poisoned arrow in regard to painful feeling, which is the practice of detachment from dharmas of the realm of desire, because painful feeling is abundant in the realm of desire.

Next, one should contemplate suffering with suffering in regard to pleasant feeling, which is the practice of detachment from dharmas of the realm of form, because pleasant feeling is superior in the realm of form, and because pleasure is the root of delighting in and enjoying birth and death. Therefore the Buddha encourages the contemplation of pleasure as suffering.
However, the essential nature of all pleasant feeling is pleasure, because it benefits and nourishes.
It is also called suffering, because it is impermanent and subject to change.
When it is contemplated as pleasure, it can cause bondage, because delighting in pleasure is the root of birth and death.
When it is contemplated as suffering, it can cause liberation, because aversion to suffering can transcend birth and death.
The Buddha, because contemplation of suffering can cause liberation, encourages sentient beings to contemplate pleasure as suffering.

Later, one should contemplate impermanence with the two non-perceiving [minds]. This is the practice of detachment from formless dharmas, because their lifespan is extremely long. Fearing that sentient beings would take them to be permanent, [the Buddha] exhorted them to contemplate impermanence, like borrowed ornaments.

Therefore, we know that the Buddha exhorts such contemplation to make sentient beings practice detachment from dharmas in the three realms. One cannot cite this to deny the existence of pleasant feeling. Because the existence of pleasant feeling in saá¹ƒsÄra is a firmly established tenet that cannot be shaken.
The discussion on the side has been completed. We should return to the correct discussion.
Among these four noble truths that have been explained, how many are conventional and how many are ultimate?
In this regard, one group says:
Two are conventional and two are ultimate.
Another group says:
Three are conventional, because all conditioned [dharmas] are subject to loss.
Some say:

The two truths are distinguished in terms of teachings, which means that all teachings that expound the person, cities, gardens, forests, etc., are all included in the conventional, because they are for the sake of revealing the real meaning, and are not produced from the intention to deceive others, and are therefore called truths.

All teachings that expound the aggregates, sense bases, elements, etc., are all included in the ultimate, because they are for the sake of explaining the real characteristics of dharmas, destroying the conception of a unified sentient being, etc., and are able to expound the truth, and are therefore called truths.
These four truths are able to cause sentient beings to realize the true principle, and are therefore the ultimate.
Here, the elder says this:
The three truths are both conventional and ultimate, that is, one truth of suffering is conventionally false, and the real things that it depends on are called ultimate;
The truths of accumulation and the path are also to be understood in the same way.
Only the truth of cessation cannot be said to exist, and is the same as the indeterminate dharmas that cannot be said to exist.
As a sutra says:
Does the complete extinction, separation, cessation, pacification, and disappearance of the six sense bases have any difference or no difference? Do you want to discuss this?
And so on, speaking extensively.
Now, examining the meaning and purport spoken by the elder, it contradicts and harms the characteristics of the conventional and ultimate truths.
What are the characteristics of these two truths?
Verse:
If the cognition of that [object] is destroyed, it does not exist. If wisdom analyzes the rest, it is also like this.
Like a worldly convention of a pot or water, different from this is called ultimate.
Commentary:

All composite substances, according to their suitability, generally have two kinds of essential distinctions: one can be broken down into subtle parts, and the other can be analyzed and removed by wisdom.

That is to say, regarding the composite aggregates of form, if they are broken down into subtle parts, the cognition of them is immediately destroyed. This is called conventional truth, like a pot and so on.
When pots and so on are broken and turned into shards and so on, one cannot give rise to the cognition of pots and so on again.
When a composite whole is broken into many parts, the cognition of it as a whole does not disappear, just as with water.
If one analyzes away the other dharmas with wisdom, the cognition of the whole disappears, and this is also conventional truth.
This is because when wisdom analyzes away form, etc., in water, etc., one can no longer have a cognition of water, etc.
When a thing has not yet been broken down, one uses the conventional name of the world to designate it. Because it is designated as existent, it is called conventional.
To say that there are pots, etc., in accordance with conventional truth is real and not false, and is called conventional truth, because it exists as conventional truth.
If a thing is different from this, it is called ultimate truth.

This means that when the cognition of that thing is not lost when it is broken down, and when one analyzes away other dharmas with wisdom, the cognition of that thing still exists, it is called ultimate truth, just as with form, etc.
